bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, October 25, 1928

div1.p: Carter informs Frost about the aegypti mosquito eggs, her work tracking down references, and her desire to make sure all the references in the bibliography conform with one another for the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, October 25, 1928
div1.opener:
See carbon of
of this letter as
rewritten
Book
Bibliography
Frost
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
October 25, 1928.
Dear Jack:
div1.p: In reply to your letter of October 22nd I would state

(1): That you are correct in your understanding re Bacot's
report viability of aegypti eggs after 8 months not being under pre-
cisely same circumstances as stated in our MS (i, p. 12).
Miss Brown and I rewrote the Bacot cards, which are all taken form
from the Fourth and Final Report of the British West African Com-
mission. for which you have library card. This report contains the “Summary of Conclusions” of the Third
Investigators report, containing results of Bacot's work on life
history “Stegomyia fasciata” from 1914 to 1916 (?) The Library of
the S. G. does not possess this Third Report, never received it. I know this
from having found correspondance between Father and Noble (when he was Librarian)
on the subject. We have then, copied from the Fourth and final re-
port: both the references re (i. p. 10) effect of soap on aegypti
larvae and (i. p. 12 (a and b) (our bib. card)) ) re viability aegypti eggs: with:(b)
account of the way in which they fiannally reached Malcolm MacGregor.
We also made out a card for MacGregor (1915) giving his own account
of how the eggs came into his hands (from sir James Fowler)

Of course, we should have much preferred seing Bacot's origi-
nal report in vol. iii. Father did see it. He states this in his
correspondance with Gen. Noble. However, the S. G's Library can
give us no suggestions as to how to get a copy. Miss Brown, however, says
that the 1st. 2nd. and 4th. and final reports were presented to hthe
S. G's Library by the Prudential Insurance Co. of America,
Newark, N. J.
and suggests that we might write them and see if they could tell us
us
-2-
where we could see a copy, or that possibly they might lend us one
themselves. Do you think it is worth while? And, if so, wouldn't
they be more apt to lend it to you than to us? I'm not trying to
shirk writing letters (much as I hate 'em!) its just that one wants
to be sure of getting what one goes after.

For the latter part of your paragraph re vol. iii Investigators reports. I don't think
its a different class of publication from the other reports as J. and vols.
A. Churchill of London also published the paper backed copies of the Fourth and Final Report and
i and ii. These (i and ii) are also published in the Y. F. Bureau
Bulletins. I am enclosing data on the missing Investigators Report (v. iii)

2): Would it be asking too much if, in the future, when you re-
turn bibliographic cards for further information, you have Miss Fred-
erick enclose or send a copy of the library card also; or else copy all data on library
card on the bibliographic card? It would save us a lot of time in
looking things up, [unclear] You see, on account of the time
element involved, we only put enough data on our bibliographic cards
to identify them with the library cards, and without the latter we
have to duplicate a good deal of our work

3): I am enclosing library and bibliographic card for Father's
article read in Australia (1923). Haven't given[unclear] pagination (Father's MS) on bib-
liographic card as I assume you have it, and I would have to go through
the MS to find it. If you haven't it, of course, I'll be glad to get
it for you, but I assume you have a bibliographic card with the pagina-
tion.

4): By the way, this is dealing in “futures,” but before the
bibliography (library cards) is typed, may Miss Brown and I please go
over the library cards with you? We are extremely anxious to do this both in
order to learn your wishes concerning certain of the cards and also to
to
-2-
rewrite any that may not conform to a uniform order of proceedure.
Please don't think I'm getting “set” in my ways from my very small ex-
perience of working in libraries, and with librarians, but I'm sure
you agree with me that the “manner” as well as the “matter” counts, al-
though “differing in degree.”

5): I am enclosing a note from Morley, in answer to my inquiry
re filling in our outline maps etc. Not very satisfactory, but better
than I had hoped, if he even gets someone else interested in part of the
work. No data on the bibliographic refs. I asked him for. However, we
got the one on the Book of the Jew ourselves.

6): No news from L. O. Howard's librarian re the references she
asked me to turn over to her

Don't hesitate to ask us to do anything in the world we can for
you. You've got the really hard part of the work and even the smallest
thing we can do to make it easier will be a privelege.
With much love to the Susans,
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Enclosures.
Dr. Wade H. Frost,
School of Hygine and Public Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Md.
